creator: teo8976@gmail.com
text:
Apparently the User directive can only be set in the "server config" context, not in a directory or a .htaccess.

I know, that is as documented.

There is no valid reason why that shouldn't be allowed (actually I wonder if there is ANY directive at all that shouldn't be allowed in all contexts). I guess there may be security reasons for that to be discouraged, but not forbidden/impossible.

creator: covener@gmail.com
text:
The directive is not accepted in those contexts because there's no impl to allow the server to change identities (laterally) on individual threads these configs
are read and merged.
clarifying comment #2: This module can't change identiy per-request, so the config can't be per directory/htaccess/URL.
creator: covener@gmail.com
teo8976@gmail.com
text: And is it something that couldn't be implemented in any possible way, or rather something that reveals a weakness in Apache's current architecture?

(In reply to teo8976 from comment #3)
> And is it something that couldn't be implemented in any possible way, or
> rather something that reveals a weakness in Apache's current architecture?

I don't think so.  Similar things are implemented in modules like mpm_itk and mod_privileges (and IBM's mod_authnz_saf) but they don't piggyback on the User directive.  

There's a lot more to worry about when you start doing something per-request vs
once per process.
